EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 2021 RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM UPDATE



A Risk Management Program has been implemented at the Arkema Inc., Houston, Texas production facility (Houston Plant) to reduce the risk of accidental releases of hazardous materials. This Risk Management Plan summarizes the management, administrative, procedural and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to the community of hazardous chemical releases.



ARKEMA POLICIES FOR HEALTH, ENVIRONMENT AND SAFETY



Risk management and safety are core principles at Arkema. Arkema is committed to conducting its operations in a safe, responsible manner and to reduce risks to health and the environment. Commitment to health, environment, and safety (HES) starts with the CEO. Senior management routinely dedicates time to review HES matters.  Emphasis on safety is carried through to the facility level, where the Plant Manager and the Safety Committee regularly review safety performance, take corrective actions and strive for continuous improvement. Arkema's HES programs include policies, procedures, standards, and guidance materials designed to fulfill Arkema's commitment to health, environment and safety.  These materials include Risk Management Program guidance to assist our facilities to prevent and/or reduce the risk of accidents.  Should an accidental hazardous substance release occur, we also have implemented a comprehensive Emergency Response Program to promptly respond, address, and minimize the consequences of the release.



FACILITY IDENTIFICATION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES IN COVERED PROCESSES 



The Arkema Houston Plant is located at 2231 Haden Road, Houston, Texas. The facility manufactures mercaptans and sulfides.  One substance used and produced within the facility is a regulated substance under 40 CFR 68, the EPA Risk management Program (RMP) rule, specifically, Carbon Disulfide (CS2). The plan also includes a description of the training program for all employees in relevant emergency response procedures and procedures for review and update, as appropriate, of the response plan, to reflect changes at the facility and to ensure that employees are informed of these changes.

The site participates in monthly Channel Industries Mutual (Aid) and bi-monthly Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) meetings to communicate and coordinate with regional emergency response and industry partners. 





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Chemical safety has been a part of the working culture at the facility for many years. Chemical exposure risks to employees and the public have been minimized through ongoing internal risk reduction efforts as well as regulatory requirements.  Improvements to the safety program have include implementation of behavior based safety and additional accident investigation training.  Additional facility improvements include upgrades in the process control systems of a production unit and enhancements to security measures.
